Yet seeing it gutted by fire was still not as painful as what the rioters did to the adjacent mosque.“We were targeted because we are Muslim,” she said. “All the shops belonging to Muslims were burnt, while none of the Hindu shops were touched. They want to single us out, to separate us from the other religions.”She said Hindus and Muslims in the neighbourhood had “never had any problems”.“We have always prayed together, Hindus and Muslims, in mosques and temples. We have always believed that we are all equal.”Like the other residents, Parveen says she bears no ill feelings for her Hindu neighbours, saying that when the mob first came from outside “they tried to save us”.I am just very sad for the situation my family is now inBut she says she doesn’t know whether the situation will calm down across the city after what happened. She is just thankful she wasn’t home to see the mosque attacked. “It is totally broken and burnt, we feel worse about that than what happened to our own homes. We were so surprised when we heard they targeted the mosque, we never thought that people could be capable of such a thing.”A little down the road from the burnt-out mosque, shattered shop fronts and piles of debris, a group of Hindu neighbours watch the clear-up and are nervous about speaking to the media.Trump to press India PM on anti-Muslim law Labour MP Abrahams denied entry to India and ‘treated like criminal’Death toll rises to 24 in Delhi riots with mosque set on fireModi on course for big defeat as Delhi rejects ‘poisonous’ campaignA 39-year-old man, who asked not to be named, said he welcomed prime minister Narendra Modi’s call for calm on Wednesday afternoon, but that it should have come on Monday.He admits the situation is “very tense”.&nbsp“We have always been living together amicably here, there was no tension, we spent our childhoods together. Now these outsiders have come in and this has happened, and it is the people living here who have to deal with the tension.”He points to four armed police officers sitting outside the burnt-out mosque. “At least there is some protection now, but we were expecting it earlier. There should have been some procedure in place,” he saidFor some, though, the four officers provide little comfort. A Muslim man whose house across the road from the mosque was burnt, who did not give his name, said the violence had turned into “the most terrible outcome possible” for this neighbourhood.We were so surprised when we heard they targeted the mosque, we never thought that people could be capable of such a thingClearly nervous, he says he is only returning briefly to retrieve any key documents that – he hopes – may have survived the fire. “All the documents, all the possessions we have, we had to just leave them behind and just run for our lives,” he said. “If they are not there, how will I get a job? These attacks are not just damaging property, they are ruining people’s lives.”Share your thoughts and debate the big issuesJoin the discussionPlease be respectful when making a comment and adhere to our CommunityYou may not agree with our views, or other users’, but please respond to them respectfullySwearing, personal abuse, racism, sexism, homophobia and other discriminatory or incitefulDo not impersonate other users or reveal private information about third partiesWe reserve the right to delete inappropriate posts and ban offending users without notificationYou can find our Community Guidelines in full here.Create a commenting name to join the debateOnly letters and numbers acceptedFollow replies to this article --Follow replies to my comment --There are no comments yet - title: jane moore tackle trolls yorkshire tea
story: Yorkshire Tea got trolled.Yep, that’s right. An inanimate object consisting of mesh and leaves bore the full, bilious brunt of virtue-signalling nastiness from those who have probably also been hash-tagging the crap out of #bekind for the past week.“If I was Yorkshire Tea I’d be very worried about my supporters all being racist Brexiteers — perhaps their super-Brit TV ad is responsible ” said one of the politer posts. Others advocated that the brand should be boycotted.A spokesman for Yorkshire Tea responded: “On Friday, the Chancellor shared a photo of our tea.Politicians do that sometimes . We weren’t asked or involved — and we said so the same day. Lots of people got angry with us all the same.”That’s because trolls aren’t interested in the whys, wherefores or, quite frankly, any context at all.They’re simply virtue-signalling from a position of self-bestowed righteousness to try to give meaning — via their target’s legion of followers — to their own sad existence.Yorkshire Tea’s response was impressively measured, but the last line has all of us thinking: “Who are these worrying idiots ”Last week it was reported that actor Freddie Fox was spat at in the street because of something his cousin Laurence said on the BBC’s Question Time.His cousin. Not even Laurence himself, who, by the way, should also be able to walk the streets without fearing physical or even aggressively verbal repercussions from someone who simply disagrees with his opinion.When moronic irrationality is restricted to the echo chamber of Twitter, it can be switched off and ignored.But when it spills out of the Twittersphere and impacts on a victim’s family or livelihood, then surely society as a whole must unite to stop it Because, one day, it could be you. Or, worse, your children.Former Met detective Philip Grindell was called in to help politicians deal with online abuse, which rose by  per cent last year.After retiring he helped a “global icon” who was scared for their le.“It was a famous person who was getting death threats,” says Philip, , who has now started a company called Dfuse Global to anticipate and assess the risk of online abuse.He discovered the death threats were coming from someone in the UK who had mental health issues and weren’t considered a risk to the personal safety of his client.Several years ago, Sky News confronted a woman who had repeatedly trolled the McCanns after the disappearance of their daughter Madeleine in .The woman, in her s, who had, “previously grappled with mental illness”, killed herself just days after being confronted.So tackling online trolling is clearly a minefield to navigate, but that doesn’t mean we shouldn’t try.Just because much of it comes from a place of deep sadness or instability in the troll’s le, why should that allow them to inflict damage on other people with impunity This isn’t about disagreeing with someone’s views in a rational, well-argued way.It’s about downright nastiness and threats to someone’s mental or physical well-being. And it needs to be tackled by the State, not just private companies.We have to provide full ID before we board a plane, so why not insist on it when setting up an online account which must include our real name followed by a unique number Then, currently anonymous trolls might think twice before whipping up hate about someone they don’t even know and we can all drink our teain peace.OH gawd, here it comes again – the tyranny of a “no make-up” photo posted by Hollywood glitterati.Stop. It. Now.The latest salvo was fired by Gwyneth Paltrow, who hosted a “natural” dinner party to promote her well-being website Goop and invited, among others, Demi Moore and Kate Hudson.Demi, who has spent £squillion on cosmetic surgery, looked great. As well she might.Equally, I once got in a lt with Kate Hudson, who is quite simply one of the most stunning women I have ever seen.And then we have Gwynnie herself, who has the radiant glow of a woman who spends the national debt of a small country on skin treatments and products.The reality, of course, is that there’s little meaning to this “no make-up” dinner party other than for the attendees to show how great they look.Meanwhile, those dealing only with what God gave them remain judged by the sentiment once expressed by beauty guru Helena Rubinstein.“There are no ugly women, only lazy ones.”THE McDonald’s Quarter Pound- er Fan Clubhas plans to launch a range of candles with smells such as burger, ketchup and onion.That’s as “eeeeeeew” as Gwyneth Paltrow’s Smells Like My Vagina candle.The, er, burning question is: What’s wrong with the old stalwarts of fig or gardenia A FORMER friend of paedophile Jeffrey Epstein’s right-hand woman Ghislaine Maxwell has told the FBI of a potentially relevant conversation they once had.“She said many things . . . ” reveals Christina Oxenburg.“Stuff like: ‘Jeffrey and I have everyone on videotape!’”Interesting.Could this perhaps explain Prince Andrew’s haste to cross the Atlantic and share a walk in the park simply to, he claims, break off the friendship with a man he also claims he didn’t know that well Or was it to find outthere were videos that he should be worried about from his time enjoying Epstein’s hospitality AL PACINO, , has been dumped by his -year-old girlfriend Meital Dohan.“I tried to deny it, but he is already an elderly man,” she says with refreshing candour.“So even with all my love, it didn’t last.”In other words, he’s very set in his ways, probably a little curmudgeonly at times and “the nursing years” are looming.THIS, believe it or not, is former “First Baby” Leo Blair – born when dad Tony was in situ at No Downing StreetIt feels like five minutes ago . . . but he’s now .Reasons to feel old: Part .THE maker of Barbie is bringing out three “inspirational women dolls” in the shape of ex-tennis champ Billie Jean King, hero nurse Florence Nightingale and singer Ella Fitzgerald, complete with “authentic clothing”.Nice idea, but let’s see how it pans out.Chances are they’ll end up in the “Barbie box” with all the others – dressed in a boob tube, sequined leggings and their hair in wonky plaits.Probably because we’d end up with a tuneless busker called Singy McSingface.THE WM Bar-B-Q Burger bar in Honolulu, Hawaii, has been serving its client favourite, the Royal Burger, since .Last time I looked they weren’t locked in litigation with The Queen.That’s because no one in their right mind would ever associate a burger restaurant with the British monarchy.The same, however, cannot be said of The Duke and Duchess of Sussex.One of them was born royal, they both enjoyed a breathtakingly expensive royal wedding, undertook royal dutiesand received money from the Duchy of Cornwall, which the reigning son of the current British monarchinherits.So while Harry and Meghan’s little barb that The Queen doesn’t have legal jurisdiction in the US over the word royal is correct, the notion that their use of the word isn’t inextricably linked to the British crown is patent nonsense and Her Majesty is right to insist they drop it.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: woke free speech if they agree
story: Its aim, Toby says, is to “defeat the authoritarianism and intolerance that is once again threatening to destroy our liberty”.Put simply, this new union — which anyone can join — will help defend people who are being attacked, vilied, no-ed, harassed at work or hounded out of their jobs, petitioned against or subjected to Twitter mob “pile-ons” just for exercising their legal right to free speech.These days that is a lot of people. The mob’s targets know no bounds.  This “woke elite” have made it impossible to have civilised conversation and debate.Take the feminist Germaine Greer, a woman who has fought tirelessly for some  years for women’s liberation. She is now considered by some to be too frightful to listen to and there have been calls to no- her — ban her from speaking at events, usually universities.Even companies such as Yorkshire Tea are getting stick.  The firm was bombarded with complaints at the weekend, with people expressing outrage because the new Chancellor, Rishi Sunak, posted a photo of himself on social media making a cup of tea with the brand.Sunak’s crime is being a Conservative. Yorkshire Tea’s crime was to allow the Conservative Chancel-or to drink its tea. This bizarre, unreasonable, moral crusading of what I see as the “woke elite” is part of the explanation for the Conservative landslide in the last election.In my view, the Labour Party lost  seats, the second largest number it has ever lost in a single election, because ordinary people look at the Left and think they have all gone mad.This isn’t true, of course. It is a great shame for sensible, left-leaning people in Britain that the woke are giving them all such a bad name.Those on the Left must cringe with horror every time there is a Twitter pile-on when someone does some- thing that “offends”.The woke march around asthey are police, bullying everyone into thinking and speaking in a way that they deem to be acceptable.If you don’t agree, they will write to your employer and get you fired, or they will bombard you with abuse until you give in and beg for forgiveness.I should know — it has happened to me more than once. If I tweet something that offends the woke elite, they write to my governing body, Ofsted, demanding my resignation.Luckily, on Twitter one can block these self-righteous radicals, giving oneself some peace. But there was a time when our school received so many savage and bloodthirsty emails that one of my office staff had a breakdown from having to read them all.We have even received death threats. Why  Because the woke elite don’t like how we run our school. As a headmistress, I believe it is important to teach children to hear all sides of any debate and encourage them to form their own, independent views.Butone side is constantly shutting down debate with bullying tactics, no-ing and drowning people out, then how are our children ever to hear both sides When we were first opening our free school, social justice warriors determined to stop us would infiltrate our parent evenings and stand up as I was talking, shouting over me so the parents couldn’t hear what I was trying to say.Why did they do this  Because in  I gave a speech at the Conservative Party conference. I am not a Conservative but that didn’t bother my detractors. As with Yorkshire Tea, simple association with the Conservative Party means you must be evil.The woke cannot imagine that the Conservatives want a better world, just as they do. They simply disagree on how to get there.So frequent and angry have the calls for someone’s dismissal or “cancellation” become that those who would have once argued the case, the “anti-woke”, are just rolling over. It’s not worth the hassle, they say with a sigh.The “anti-woke” weren’t always this way. They are ordinary people who have simply become fed up of being browbeaten by these pseudo-moral liberators.If the woke have something truly interesting to say, then why don’t they make their arguments, stand up on a stage and explain why their beliefs are worthy At least that would have the effect of persuading people, rather than alienating them.  But the woke don’t care about being virtuous. They want only to signal it.In , too many people live in fear of what they can and cannot say. We are meant to be living in a free country.Let’s hope one day it can feel aswe do and we will no longer need a Free Speech Union.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: must avoid coronavirus hysteria economy
story: OF course the likely coronavirus pandemic is a threat to health that should be taken very seriously.But I fear the hysteria and kneejerk reactions currently taking place across the country could have an unnecessary impact on our economy and way of le.It’s essential that sensible precautions are put in place.That doesn’t mean cancelling holidays, shutting down workplaces and stopping children going to school.For example, the Chevron Corporation today sent home  employees from its London office because one of their employers could have coronavirus. Of course, they could also just have a cold.But nevertheless traders, exploration and refining unit staff were told to work remotely – something that is not possible in many businesses.Some folk are being asked to self-quarantine for two weeks simply because they went on holiday to northern Italy.It’s getting even more needlessly dramatic within education.As it stands, Public Health England are NOT advising any schools to close.But eight now have been, while another  have quarantined pupils, forcing them to stay at home with their parents for a fortnight.In the most ridiculous case so far, an Essex primary school has been shut by its headmaster because one of its teachers spent half-term in Italy. That teacher is reportedly not sick or exhibiting any of the symptoms of coronavirus.We’ve already seen the very real cost to the market of such overreach, with £ billion wiped off the FTSE  in just  hours and the shares of travel companies like Tui and Easy Jet plummeting.The government is right and responsible to consider worst-case scenarios and plan appropriately.The Sun today revealed details of an official report showing that a catastrophic outbreak could see  per cent of Brits come down with coronavirus and , die.Of the  people tested for the virus in the UK,  have tested positive and eight of those have now been discharged.The reality is that for the vast majority of healthy people Coronavirus will not be fatal.Doing the basics right now – like washing your hands regularly and using tissues – will actually do more to help curb the spread than costly grand gestures.We must be vigilant and safe, but avoid Coronavirus hysteria.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: harry nations favourite royal brits welcome him home
story: But while he will come to terms with the HRH change, I suspect he will take a lot longer to get over the loss of his cherished military links.I am delighted we will see him in the Netherlands this summer at the Invictus Games, his brilliant idea that has given so many wounded servicemen and women a newfound purpose.Andthe reaction he got in Scotland is anything to go by he will get a well-deserved reception from everyone.When I saw him smiling and hugging people at the event in Edinburgh, the Harry I have known and respected all his le was back.The fact he flew on a commercial airline from his new home in Canada and travelled by train from London to Edinburgh made me think the private jets and the lectures may be a thing of the past.He may want people to call him plain old Harry, but I shall continue to call him “Sir”.To me he will always be the most popular member of the Royal Family since his mother. And from the reaction we saw the people think the same, too.Good luck on this adventure in America and Canada — but I don’t think it will be long before he misses this country so much that he will want to come back and become a fully fledged member of the Royal Family.I hope his self-imposed exile is short-lived, but at the moment he is doing what his we wants and that is commendable. But the grass always looks greener over in the neighbouring field.So, Harry,you get fed up of making speeches to rich businessmen and you want to come back, just jump on the first plane and come home. We will welcome you with open arms.The love this country has for him has never stopped. As far as the nation is concerned he is still their number one member of the Royal Family.Harry is one of those instinctive people who do and say the first thing that comes into their head and when I saw him hugging people in Edinburgh I remembered why the public will always love him.Just before Christmas, when he visited a school in Luton, the students were queuing up to give him a hug before he left. That’s the Harry I know and love. We will miss him.Having toured with Harry for many years, he was a photographer’s dream — even when the tables were turned on me.In a youth club in New Zealand he was asked to put his painted hand on the wall, which he did.And then he rushed across the room and planted it on my head, as you see in the picture above.When we washed up afterwards he rebuked me for telling the whole nation on TV that morning he was going bald — just like his dad.I know his father, Prince Charles, is upset that his son is leaving and William, his best friend for many years, will also be sad to see his brother go.But the Queen has given him a year to review it and he will be welcomed like the prodigal sonhe decides his future is here back in Britain in the world’s number one family.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: blaming tories for life expectancy drop is lazy
story: And worse — for the poorest of us, it’s actually reduced in some parts of the country.That’s the headline story from the latest report into how long we live. At the end of the last decade, men could expect to live . years and women were still well ahead on ..But in my patch, the North East of England, le expectancy for women has actually fallen a little.The report comes from a bloke called Sir Michael Marmot. He blames economic inequality and austerity for what he calls the UK’s “lost decade”.I have no doubt whatsoever that poverty shortens theof a le. And low wages — especially in the North East — mean that for too long people have been struggling by on very little indeed.But Sir Michael also has a bit of skin in the game. He has been arguing for decades about social inequality and its effects upon health.Fair enough. But this has given rise to headlines about evil Tories killing people. The usual stuff.If you listened to the coverage of his report on the BBC, you’d think Boris Johnson and co were wandering around the country strangling impoverished pensioners as they queue up in food banks. And cackling maniacally.But is it really quite so simple as that  Is it really all about poverty Sir Michael admits that  per cent might be attributable to new flu strains which have arrived here as a consequence of increased globalisation.Bird flu, Sars and now the coronavirus.That’s not all, though. As we keep being told, the country is in the grip of an obesity epidemic.And the areas where obesity is at its greatest are also those where le expectancy is at its lowest. Being fat isn’t the consequence of poverty. It’s a result primarily of a lack of exercise and, secondly, a poor diet.Given that the NHS and Government have been banging on about obesity for a decade, might not that have something to do with it, Sir Michael Then there’s alcohol. We drink a lot of it. And by and large it’s not terribly good for us. The trend in the past  years is that women are catching up with men in their intake. I wonderthat might also have an effect on those le expectancy tables  Again, nothing to do with poverty.What about women working  Le expectancy for men always lagged behind women — and we were told that this was because men went out to work.Now that women work too, would we not expect the le expectancies for each sex to draw closer together And then this. During the past  years we have welcomed more than six million immigrants to the UK. The le expectancy in their home countries is way below that of the average in the UK —  years below in the case of Pakistan, for example, and three years in the case of Poland. Many will arrive still with the legacy of poor health treatment in their original countries. That must, surely, affect the statistics.My argument isn’t that austerity isn’t in there somewhere. Simply that there are a few more factors to take into account before we blame the Tories, once again, for killing people.The bloke had just got back from Iran, where the virus has been spreading. The experts have been warning of a possible , deaths in the UK. We need to remember that is a very-worst-case scenario based upon a lot of “s”.But just to be on the safe side, shouldn’t we be carrying out compulsory checks on all visitors flying in from flu-stricken areas Instead of allowing people to “self-report” IN the coffee plantations of Guatemala, Central America, kids lug sacks of coffee beans around for eight hours a day.For this they are paid the princely sum of £. The coffee is used by posh coffee company Nespresso in its overpriced capsules.Nespresso’s “brand ambassador” is the liberal luvvie actor George Clooney. He got more than £million from the company.How about you give some of that money back to the child labourers, George You want to change the world, make it a better place Then enable those children to live dignied lives without back-breaking work all day.I’M proud to have signed up to Toby Young’s Free Speech Union, to defend our freedom of speech.I had to break a pledge of mine to join it.It’s Lent right now – the season of the year when traditionally you give something up. Well, I’d decided to give up donating to charities for a month or so. But happy to make a very noble exception. Never before in our democratic country has free speech been so under threat.It’s OK for gobby old tossers like Toby and me – we have a  to speak. But too often people are hounded from their jobs simply for expressing an opinion. Or barred from speaking at universities in case they upset someone.Or get a midnight visit from the Old Bill because they happened to like a joke about a transgender person.The fightback starts here. Later next month I’ll be visiting universities to unveil a Charter for Academic Freedom, drawn up by my political party, the Social Democrats. Nothing is more precious than the freedom to express one’s opinion.If it offends someone , my suggestion is: OK, sure, now get over it.He was very right-on, was Harvey. Had all the politically correct opinions. Much loved by the Obamas, of course.Always the way, isn’t it  The more a bloke tells you he’s a liberal and a feminist, the more women should reach for the can of Mace.I HAD a bowl of Alpen this week, for the first time in  years.My daughter’s just got a hamster and its food reminded me of the cereal I used to eat as a young teen. Came in a black box with a mountain on it. My mum bought it because she thought it looked posh and foreign.Indeed, I thought it came from Switzerland. It was actually made in Kettering, Northants.Anyway, I had a bowl of the stuff and couldn’t work out why it wasn’t as nice as I remembered.My Facebook friends told me it was because they’ve cut the sugar content. Probably that’s right.But isn’t it also that NOTHING tastes as good as how you remember it  Not Alpen, not Mars bars, not Monster Munch.And definitely not Heinz Sandwich Spread, which tastes to me these days like paint stripper.Have to say, the site seems to me to be run as a kind of grooming parlour for the benefit of middle-aged pervs. But it’s not just that. The longer your kids – and especially the girls – spend online, the greater their chances of developing depression and other mental illnesses.They also end up with a much shorter attention span. Because they spend their days swiping backwards and forwards in a nanosecond.If we’re to avoid rearing a generation of doolally morons, we need to ration the time they spend online.It’s down to us parents to do that – not the State and not even the companies who run the godawful sites.WAS out walking with the dog this week. Saw this weird thing in the sky.Kind of a yellowy-orange. Circular. Looked up a few moments later and it was gone. I had this feeling that I’d seen it before – a long, long time ago. But can’t put a name to it.When will this miserable weather end If you knew you were a bee, would you be happy  I’m not sure I would.One bee told me yesterday: “Bit of a downer, really.“Suddenly realised I’m going to spend my entire le carting loads of pollen back to some enormous idle cow in the hive.“I’d much rather be a wasp, frankly. At least their arses don’t fall off when they sting someone.”Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: coronavirus closes primary school parent tests positive
story: Chief Medical Officer Chris Witty said school closures could be key in reducing mass gatheringsthe disease becomes a pandemic.He said: Because one of the things thats clear with this virus, much more so than with the flu, is anything we do were going to have to do for quite a long time – probably more than two months.One school closed yesterday after a parent ed infected with coronavirus from a Tenere hotel where  Brits are quarantined - in one of three new cases.Burbage Primary School in Buxton, Derbyshire, sent out a WhatsApp alert warning people to stay away last night -as fears spread the deadly bug is taking hold in Britain.Medical staff in hazmat suits were seen visiting a street close to the school as authorities work to contain the virus.Northern Ireland confirmed its first positive test this evening - bringing the total number of people diagnosed with Covid- in the UK to .The Derbyshire parent had ed from the H Costa Adeje Palace in Tenere, where hundreds of people are being confined after a coronavirus outbreak.According to the Derbyshire Times, the school confirmed that the patients child went to school as normal on Monday and Tuesday this week.In its latest message to parents, Burbage Primary School said: “We are now in a position to confirm that the parent has not entered the school site since theirfrom holiday.“School remains closed for the rest of the week as a precautionary measure as cleaning takes place.”Public Health England is contacting people who had close contact with the parent.One mum at the school told the Sun Online: “It’s very worrying because any number of people could be stricken with the bug and may not even be aware.“Who would have thought our little town in the middle of nowhere would be hit. It’s caused a lot of alarm bells and locals are quite fearful.”Another said: “Others could have caught the virus through contact with the Buxton resident and not even been diagnosed. It could escalate and that’s a concern for us.”But other parents are making the most of the “quality time off” with their kids.One dad said: “We’re blessed with coronavirus! It snowed overnight and we’ve all been out sledging then having a long lunch in the local pub.It’s full of parents and pupils. The children aren’t complaining.”senior doctors from hospitals across England have said that the NHS would crumblethe number of those infected reaches pandemic levels.The situation would mean doctors having to make “tough decisions” in order to free up beds.Buxton Medical Practice, which is less than a mile from Burbage Primary School, has also closed today due to a confirmed case of coronavirus.In a statement on its website, the surgery says it will undergo a deep clean, adding it is not yet known how long it will be closed for.Burbage Primary School will also undergo a thorough deep clean in a bid to halt the bugs spread.The schools head, Anthony Tierney said: We are shut, it is just a precaution. I can’t say anything more at the moment.”Does your child go to the school  Do you know the family affected  Email us at britta.zeltmann@the-sun or call   . You can WhatsApp us on   It brings the number of schools closed amid coronavirus fears to  across the UK, as  others turn away pupils and teachers.But Burbage Primary School is believed to be the first to close due to a confirmed case of the Covid- virus.In a joint statement with Derbyshire Council, Public Health England said: The case is a resident of Derbyshire and became infected whilst in Tenere.Close contacts will be given health advice about symptoms and emergency contact details to usethey become unwell in the  days after contact with the confirmed cases.Guests at the H Costa Adeje Palace in Tenere have been told to self-isolate in their rooms after an Italian couple were diagnosed with the bug.They have been handed thermometers and told to write down their own readings, while others are moving around the hotel and going to the pool and restaurant even though they have been advised to stay in.According to the El Paris newspaper,  guests from  countries are in the hotel, along with around  workers.It is reported that two security perimeters remain around the hotel, while a field hospital has been set up to treat anybody with coronavirus symptoms.Meanwhile, another Brit suspected of having coronavirus was wrongly told to go to hospital by NHS  operators after ing from Milan in Italy.Paul Godfrey, from Walsall, West Midlands, claims he was left coughing for  minutes in the packed hospital waiting room without a mask - before medics in hazmat suits whisked him into cubicle to be tested.The advice Mr Godfrey received contracts official infection control guidelines, which state anybody suspected of having the deadly bug should self-isolate immediately.PHEs medical director Prof Paul Cosford said schools had to take dficult decisions given the complexity of the issues that theyre facing.He said: Of course, schools have dficult decisions to take - a whole range of issues to take into account and we are able to talk to them about their specic circumstances and help them make the right decisions for them.But what I would say is that our general advice is not to close schools.Coronavirus has seen a number of international events disrupted as the deadly bug grips Britain and Europe.Irelands Six Nations rugby clash against Italy was postponed yesterday amid fears of the virus - as organisers said they were monitoring the situation very closely.The game was scheduled to take place in Dublin on March  with thousands of Italian supporters, many from the regions most affected by the outbreak, expected to make the trip.The organisers of the London Marathon in April have also said they are monitoring the spread of the virus closely.

title: number of people migrating to britain from outside the eu is at its highest ever level
story: Net migration numbers from non-EU countries reached a quarter of a million international migrants in the last year, new figures released today revealed.The number of people arriving in the UK from non-EU countries has peaked in the year to September , the Office of National Statistics said.Meanwhile, net migration numbers from non-EU countrieshave reached their highest point since  - at ,.Around , people moved to the UK from outside the bloc in the year ending September , while , people left the country.Arrivals of migrants from within the EU, however, have hit their lowest levels since before the Brexit vote.Only , more people from Europe moved to the UK than left.Thats compared to around , in late  and early .The number of people moving from eastern European countries even hit negative levels - with , more people leaving the UK than arriving in the same time period.Director of the Centre for International Migration, Jay Lindop said today: Since , immigration for work has decreased because of fewer EU citizens arriving for a job.She said that immigration for study was now the main reason for people coming to the UK from outside the EU - particularly Chinese and Indian students.There were , sponsored study visas granted in the year ending December  - more than double the number in . per cent of those visas were granted to Chinese nationals, and  per cent to Indian nationals.The new numbers came out after the government announced their new points based system earlier this month, which is set to overhaul British immigration controls.It will create new rules including making sure that anyone coming to the UK has to earn at least £, a year - and they will have to make sure they speak English well too.

contracting coronavirus in China - bringing the total to nine.Another four cases were recorded just a week later after being flown back to the UK from the plague cruise ship, the Diamond Princess.The title: sell channel 4 leftie luvvie propaganda
story: WITH all the focus on Boris Johnson’s necessary desire to rein in the BBC, one might think that the focus has shted away from that other Government-owned broadcaster. The one that is far more biased, out of control and in need of immediate reform.But this week we were provided with a happy reminder that Channel ’s future is by no means certain.MPs close to the Prime Minister revealed a plan is on the table for the blatantly left-wing broadcaster to be privatised.That will be music to the ears of fair-minded folk everywhere who have seen the once-interesting and innovative station morph into a liberal propaganda network that believes it is there to humiliate the Tories and call out commercial media rivals.It’s a shocking anomaly that in the  broadcasting world, where choice for consumers is at an all-time high, C is publicly owned at all.The sort of quirky, culturally relevant, groundbreaking and erse programming that once made the channel worth having is a distant memory.Instead, we are left in the truly odd situation where one Government-owned broadcasterspent many millions of pounds to poach from another BBC a genuinely popular existing programme called The Great British Bake Off, with the result being the show’s biggest stars leaving and the ratings halving.Meanwhile, C’s lone recent success, Black Mirror, was lost to Netflix.Then there’s the sorry state of Channel  News, which makes even Newsnight look impartial.It was no surprise to me when I witnessed at the Bafta Awards last month Hugh Grant make a beeline for his pal Jon “F*** the Tories” Snow, no doubt to collude on even more coverage designed to undermine anyone who doesn’t share their anti-Press, anti-Brexit world view.Let me remind you of just a small portion of the smorgasbord of hit pieces served up by C in the past year alone.There was the “comedy” that imagined a character, based on Brexit Party leader Nigel Farage, was shot in the head while giving a speech about immigration.There was the real speech from the channel’s head of news and current affairs, Dorothy Byrne, where she attacked Boris Johnson as a “known liar”.Its news service then ly claimed the PM said “people of colour” while answering a question about democratically controlled immigration rather than “people of talent”.There was the climate change debate where C News replaced Boris with a chunk of melting ice and refused to let his stand-in Michael Gove into the venue to represent the Tories.And there was the most recent election night broadcast where a studio audience who they claimed fairly represented the political spectrum booed when the exit poll showing a massive Tory majority was announced.If any other channel had broadcast such slanted programming they would have faced sanctions from the regulator Ofcom many times over.There is literally no benefit for the Government to hang on to a broadcaster which has lost any sense of its real reason for being.C no longer provides any sort of public service broadcasting.To be completely honest, barring the odd gem, it hasn’t done since it became Big Brother TV in  and started a march towards hyper-commercialism.I am by no means saying C should not exist. Once privatised, the successful parts would be able to thrive.That would mean far more commercially viable hits like the soap Hollyoaks, and further series of popular factual series like Bake Off.And likely the end of a biased news service fronted by Mr Snow, that on Wednesday night saw its ratings plummet to just ,.HOLLYWOOD celebrity agents and PRs operate in a narcissistic system where the over-the-top needs and desires of their spoiled, A-list, millionaire clients are put above everything .There is not a moment to think of the greater good for humanity, nor even the other staff involved on a project.No constraints are placed on the ridiculous nature of the daily requests these staff members oversee, be it demands for millions of dollars more for a project, or a private jet, or three personal assistants.They know all too well thattheir famous client isn’t happy, there is a long list of other agents just waiting to step in to take their -per-cent cut of the star’s earnings.That’s why, for the past six months, there has been a growing sense of dread within the Royal Family about such a network of Hollywood vultures becoming intrinsically involved in the “business” of the monarchy.And there was most definitely reason to worry.As the Duke and Duchess of Sussex’s classless rebuke to the Queen over the use of the word “royal” showed, their new team will go for the low blow without a second thought for the damage it could cause to Crown or country.FOR years I have been campaigning for the BBC to overhaul the system that sees us put up a God-awful entry for the Eurovision Song Contest year after year.Sure, I acknowledge that we’re never going to do particularly well in the actual results, especially post-Brexit.But that’s no reason to put forward the type of total dross we have been.So this year I am celebrating – because the UK entry is actually an immediate piece of mid-tempo pop magic with a soaring chorus.Sensibly, the Beeb has signed up talented singer-songwriter James Newman to represent us with his tune My Last Breath.His record company BMG says it started the search for a song with the “sole aim of changing the perception of the contest by working with the very best UK songwriters”.James certainly has Eurovision pedigree.He won a Brit in  as co-writer of Rudimental hit Waiting All Night, has twice been nominated for Grammys and has written hit singles for Ed Sheeran, Calvin Harris and Jess Glynne.And his brother is the equally talented pop star John Newman.But now is his time to step into the spotlight himself and be able to proudly fly the Union Jack in Rotterdam this May.You can tune into Dan’s talkRADIO Drivetime slot on weekdays between pm and pm Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. story: Canadian Emmanuel Faug, his we Clémentine Ferraton and their three kids boarded a flight from Quebec City to Paris on February .However, its been reported fellow passengers then asked Air Transat cabin crew to question the family over -month-old Lilas coughing.According to Ouest-France, others on board began complaining the little girl could be infected with the killer virus.A member of the crew then approached the family and asked the mothershe could provide a medical document proving their daughter was not contagious.One flight attendant then reportedly asked a doctor on board to examine the girl who also confirmed she was fine to fly.However, its claimed the captain was not happy with the doctors diagnosis and contacted Medlink, a company specialising in aviation medical issues.He was then reportedly advised to eject the girl from the plane because she did not have a medical certicate to state she was not infected with the deadly virus.An Air Transat spokesman said: After analysing the situation, MedLink determined that the passengers medical condition posed a signicant potential risk to passengers and crew during the flight.They [MedLink] follow the recommendations of the International Air Transport Associationand the International Civil Aviation Organisationregarding contagious diseases.However, the girls mom said: We were thrown off a plane against the advice of two doctors, one in person. title: brits trapped coronavirus tenerife keep calm tan
story: Hundreds are quarantined at the Costa Adeje Palace in Tenere after five people contracted the virus.On Thursday night,  Brits were among  allowed to leave.Other guests have been issued with face masks and thermometers.German tourist Clara Walser, , was on Thursday pictured sunbathing in a bikini and mask.The student, with sister Laura, , reckoned Brits should enjoy the free booze instead of panicking.She told The Sun: “We’re going to be locked up for a while so why not spend some time sunbathing “There are lots of British people here who are panicking but my advice to them would be to try and stay calm.“It is a serious situation but we are here now, so what use does worrying do “Focus on the bright side of things, which is that the sun is out and it’s very hot.”Around  people from  countries were confined to their rooms on news of the initial outbreak.But they are now allowed out to fill up with free food and booze at the four-star hotel’s buffet.Brits at the hotel have been pictured quaffing champagne and wine during their quarantine.But one British family blasted the lack of precautions among guests.Selina Lund, , is on holiday from Yorkshire with husband Ashley, , and kids Sam, , and Violet, .She said: “The dining room was heaving. A field hospital has been set up outside to treat anyone with Coronavirus symptoms.On Thursday night the Foreign Office said it had “no plans” to fly British tourists home from their hotel lockdown in Tenere.An FCO spokeswoman said: “Were in touch with Spanish authorities but as far as were aware theres no plans for a flight at the moment.”It also emerged the Italian super-spreader at the heart of Europe’s crisis infected his pregnant we, two doctors, an elderly woman who died from the illness and at least nine others.The disaster unfolded after medics failed to test him.The -year-old man, named only as Mattia, was admitted to hospital after initially being turned away three times despite showing classic signs of the virus.Doctors at Codogno hospital - one of eleven locked down towns in northern Italy - told him he was suffering from common flu when when he first visited on February .On February  he went back back but was again sent home only totwo days later complaining of feeling unwell but because he had not been to China no test was carried out.However the following night he ed to the hospital where he was admitted and the Covid- virus infection was eventually confirmed.In that time the man infected his pregnant we, a running pal and his bar owner father who passed the virus onto several customers.He is also thought to have given the bug to doctors and nurses at Codogno who then unwittingly passed it on sparking a cluster in the town and surrounding areas.The man who is still in hospital has been dubbed Italy’s super spreader. title: national interest increase airport capacity
story: Two years ago MPs overwhelmingly approved the third runway at Heathrow. Even in that dysal Parliament it won a huge majority of .They were all aware of climate change. But they also knew this was a vital step for us as an independent trading nation outside the EU. Even the CBI, no fans of Brexit, called it a “historic decision”.But as with fracking, which could have slashed energy bills for millions and powered the UK for a generation, it has been killed off by a green lobby whose concerns, while understandable, always seem to trump our economy.The Appeal Court claims the runway bid was flawed because it failed to factor in our agreement to end emissions by . But how far will they take that argument  To any new transport infrastructure  Any new road The Government must find a way to stop its net-zero commitment, which The Sun supports, crippling our ­economy as our rivals flourish.Equally it must stop courts running a parallel government and siding with pressure groups to block key decisions taken by MPs elected to do so.It may not be in Boris Johnson’s personal interests to back a further appeal.It is, however, in the national interest to radically and rapidly increase our airport capacity — or watch business and jobs disappear across the Channel.IT is hard to fault the PM’s pledge to abandon trade talks in three monthsBrussels will not change its tune.We will need six months to prepare for new border checks and WTO terms.And EU demands are transparently ridiculous, even to its fans.It is obviously crazy to try to tie a sovereign nation to foreign courts and laws and demand rights over its fishing waters.The EU is still fed up about Brexit and keen to deter others. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailThe family of Errol Graham, who died of starvation when his benefits were cut off, have launched legal action against the Department of Work and Pensions . Errol weighed just k when his body was found by bailfs who broke into his council flat to evict him in June . His Employment and Support Allowance and Housing Benefit had been stopped in October  because he had not attended  a Work Capability Assessment on  August . His housing benefit was also later stopped. A coroner heard Mr Graham, had serious mental health dficulties including long-term depression. An inquest found his loss of income was likely to have caused huge distress. Today, Errolaposs daughter-in-law Alison Turner, sent a pre-action letter to the DWP arguing that their systems and procedures around cancelling benefits are unlawful. She also claims that the secretive investigations and reviews being conducted by the DWP into benefit-related deaths are unlawful and must be reformed. Alison, , from Nottinghamshire, argues in her case that the DWP has failed to put in place effective mechanisms to identy the risks and flaws in its system, correct them, and prevent further deaths occurring. Amongst the complaints, they argue that the termination of Errol’s benefits, and the relevant policy or system in place, were incompatible with his human rights. Alison, said: “The government owes it to Errol, his family and the country to explain why the DWP has repeatedly failed to learn from these tragedies over many years. In Errol’s memory I am determined to fight for change so that no more families have to live through the horror we have.”A DWP spokesman said: Our sympathies are with Mr Graham’s family. It would be inappropriate to comment further at this time.”Tessa Gregory, solicitor from law firm Leigh Day representing Alison, said: “One of the alarming features of Errol’s death is that according to the DWP their safeguarding policies were followed to the letter. Errol was flagged as highly vulnerable, and all the necessary steps under the policies were taken, but a decision was still made to terminate all of his benefits without finding anything out about his physical or mental health.

title: tories disappointed cash raised donors
story: NewsTories disappointed by cash raised from donors at lavish billionaires ballEXCLUSIVE Treasurers were said to have hoped theyd raise more from the Winter Party - even as new figures show they pocketed £ million in donations in the run up to the electionShareCommentsByMikey SmithPolitical Correspondent:,  FEB NewsBoris Johnson rolled out the red carpet for billionaires - but did they get their chequebooks out for him  " to FREE email alerts from Mirror - politicsSubscribeWe will use your email address only for sending you newsletters. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailTory treasurers were disappointed with the money raised at their lavish Winter Ball - even as new figures show the party pocketed £ million in the run up to Decemberaposs election. Political parties accepted a combined total of £,, in  - the largest value ever reported in one year and almost £ million more than , the year with the previous largest value of donations.The blockbuster figure was boosted by the Conservative Party attracting almost four times as much cash than the Labour Party, which reported just under £ million between October and December. Digger billionaire Lord Bamford, his son Jo and brother Mark donated a total of £. million across  donations to the party. Billionaire Theatre mogul John Gore, investment banker Peter Hargreaves, former Redrow Homes boss Steve Morgan and insurance entrepreneur Peter Wood gave the party £ million each. And financier Michael Spencer gave the party £m split between two donations of £, and a further £, in smaller gts to local parties via his firm IPGL. Just hours later the Tories sent a begging email to members asking for cash to help them match Labouraposs resources. It read: Today [the partyaposs finance team] sent me an update from the Electoral Commission which confirmed that Labour accepted £. million from trade unions in Q . So now we need to redouble our efforts to raise £, by the time Labouraposs new leader is in place, or we wonapost have the resources to match them. Despite raking in hundreds of thousand of pounds from wealthy backers in an auction at Tuesdayaposs Winter Ball, senior Conservatives were said to be disappointed lots didnapost sell for more. One such lot was a day at the cricket with Chancellor Rishi Sunak, which raised £, for party coffers. It canapost carry on like this, a Tory source said. A box at a one-day international would set you back  grand evenit didnapost have the Chancellor in it. The source said donors were more willing to part with cash under Theresa Mayaposs leadership because they were scared of Jeremy Corbyn . Attendees noted PM Boris Johnson left the event very early.Meanwhile, it has emerged Lubov Chernukhin, a Russian financier whose husband is a former ally of Vladimir Putin, bought a tennis match with Mr Johnson at the event.Ms Chernukhin has previously bid hundreds of thousand of pounds to gain private access to prime ministers - including a game of tennis with David Cameron and Mr Johnson in  and a girls night out with Theresa May and a host of ministers last year. Another Tory source said while the table plan for the event had Ms Chernukhin seated with Education Secretary Gavin Williamson, she ended up sitting with Mr Johnson all night. New figures show she also donated £, to the party in the months leading up to the election. Jon Trickett MP, Labour’s Shadow Cabinet Office Minister said: “For years the UK economy has failed to work for the majority of people in this country, instead benefiting an increasingly small few in the City of London. “These latest donations confirm that the Conservative Party is the Party of this few, and that they cannot be trusted to govern in the interests of the many. “The time is long overdue for an overhaul of our political finance rules, which fail to protect our democracy from undue influence.” Meanwhile, the Liberal Democrats were handed £ million by former Labour minister Lord Sainsbury - an outspoken opponent of Brexit . Lord Sainsbury, once the UKaposs largest political donor and a minister under Tony Blair , said in  that he would no longer be making contributions to parties.The Brexit Party declared £,, in donations during the same period. The bulk of the donations to Nigel Farage’s party came from businessman Christopher Harborne, who handed them £. million across just three months. The sum takes his total donations to the Brexit Party to £. million. Investment tycoon Jeremy Hosking gave the party a further £,. Louise Edwards, Director of Regulation at the Electoral Commission, said: “In the final three months of , political parties reported accepting the highest value of donations in one quarter since our records began. “The value of the donations accepted by parties in the last quarter exceeded the previous high, from , by almost £ million.

title: uks 9 demands brexit trade
story: NewsUKs  demands for a Brexit trade deal - and why theyll start a fight with the EUThe UK government is warning Boris Johnson could walk away from Brexit trade deal talks as soon as June. So what is Britain demanding - and why is it a problem for Brussels  Here are the  sticking pointsShareCommentsByDan BloomOnline Political EditorMikey SmithPolitical Correspondent:,  FEB NewsBoris Johnson and Michel Barnier are preparing for battle over a Brexit trade deal" to FREE email alerts from Mirror - politicsSubscribeWe will use your email address only for sending you newsletters. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailBritain and the EU have kick-started frantic talks on a Brexit trade deal as both sides lay out their demands. The EU published its -page negotiating directives on Tuesday - and now the UK has hit back with a -page document of its own. It confirms Boris Johnsonaposs plans to insist on full control over key areas including state aid, workersapos rights, environmental standards and fishing rights. And that means it heralds major rows over areas including business competition - the so-called level playing field - after No junked previous commitments to Brussels.Whataposs more, Boris Johnson will threaten to walk away from the talks as soon as Junethings are not moving fast enough.These are only the starting points, of course. If there is a trade deal, both sides will probably meet somewhere in the middle. Butthey start too far apart, itaposll scupper any hope of an agreement and weaposll be left high and dry. These talks are crucial for the future of the UK. If we donapost have a trade deal with the EU by  December , transitional rules will expire. That means itaposll be harder to travel, new checks will spring up, and billions of pounds worth of goods will be whacked with major tarfs as they pass through ports like Dover. Yet itaposs understood the UK government has no plan to publish an impact assessment of todayaposs planned deal. Meaning weaposll have little clue the extent of how it hits businesses and your family. Hereaposs our guide to the key sticking points in the coming talks - the areas where they could fall apart. . Fishing  WHAT THE EU SAYS: The EU wants to let EU fishermen continue fishing in UK waters - avoiding any economic dislocation. It wants a fishing arrangement to follow some EU laws. And crucially, it wants a new fisheries deal to be signed and ratied by  July . EU Brexit chief Michel Barnier said a free trade deal with the UK had to include fishing rights or there wonapost be any agreement at all. He added: Fisheries is part of a package as regards our trade relations, which are to be discussed, and that package is one you canapost break up. There will be no ambiguity at all around that.WHAT THE UK SAYS: The UK says Britain must become an independent coastal state. That means agreeing annual negotiations on access to fishing waters - and any EU vessels granted access to fish in UK waters would have to follow UK rules. The UK insists it wonapost trade away fishing rights infor a trade deal.. European courts  WHAT THE EU SAYS: To enforce the overall deal, the EU and the UK will have to agree to a dispute settlement system. The EU insists the European Court of Justice must have the final say on some disputes under this - and the dispute body must agree to follow whatever decision it makes.WHAT THE UK SAYS: The UK flat-out rejects this. The document says there will be no role for the ECJ in the dispute resolution mechanism or any of the arrangements reached between the two sides.. Extending the transition period  WHAT THE EU SAYS: The transition period will end on  December , but a joint committee can decide before July  this year to extend it by up to one or two years. EU chiefs have encouraged an extension, saying there isnapost enough time to figure out a full trade deal.WHAT THE UK SAYS: Britain has totally ruled out extension. Page four of the document states: The government will not extend the transition period. That effectively means that at the June summit,a deal doesnapost look likely by the end of the year, the UK will prepare to walk away with no trade deal.. Business competition  WHAT THE EU SAYS: The EUaposs big demand is a aposlevel playing fieldapos. This means having similar trade rules for both sides - and guaranteeing the UK canapost use leaving the EU to undercut its former partners to scoop up business. In , it would mean UK businesses get tarf-free access to EU markets. WHAT THE UK SAYS: The phrase level playing field doesnapost appear anywhere in the -page document. Britain says the trade deal should maintain effective competition laws - but this does not require regulatory alignment or linking the UKaposs rules to the EUaposs. The document explicitly adds: Both parties should have the regulatory freedom to respond to new and emerging challenges in these areas.If Britain signed up to the EUaposs request the implications would be far-reaching, limiting its abilities to strike wide-ranging deals with the rest of the world, including potentially the US.  . State aid WHAT THE EU SAYS: The EU wants the UK to keep following EU rules on aposstate aidapos - the amount of government support that can be given to industries like steel. Under EU rules, governments are allowed to provide state aid only with approval from Brussels. Any disputes would have to be dealt with through a joint process.WHAT THE UK SAYS: Britain rejects the idea of a binding aposlevel playing fieldapos - and the document proposes a more woolly commitment to be fair to both sides. It says any state-owned enterprises should operate in a fair and transparent manner and not discriminate against businesses in the other party.Effectively, theyaposre saying they wonapost sign up to EU rules, but within the terms of the agreement the UK and EU can agree not to drastically undercut each other. . Environment  WHAT THE EU SAYS: EU leaders say the UK must uphold all of Brusselsapos environmental standards that are in force as at  December . Britain would also have to commit to the EUaposs climate change targets where relevant.And the UK would need a system of carbon pricing to cost pollution that has at least the same effectiveness and scope as the EUaposs. Brussels wants Britain to simply link its emissions trading system to the EUaposs. WHAT THE UK SAYS: Again, Britain rejects a binding aposlevel playing fieldapos. Instead it calls for aposreciprocal commitments not to weaken or reduceapos environment standards on either side.. Workersapos rights  WHAT THE EU SAYS: The document says Britain must not lower any labour or social protection laws below the level of the EUaposs as at  December . Those include workplace rights health and safety consultation rules and fair conditions. This stops short of dynamic alignment - following EU rules as they change.WHAT THE UK SAYS: As with state aid and the environment, Britain agrees to include reciprocal commitments not to weaken workersapos rights laws. But the UK rejects the demand to follow EU laws, saying the agreement should recognise the right of each party to set its labour priorities and adopt or mody its labour laws.. A security treaty  WHAT THE EU SAYS: The EU wants to include security and defence as part of the talks on a trade deal. Thataposs because the UK has the upper hand in this, as one of the continentaposs leading powers.WHAT THE UK SAYS: A UK source confirmed the British government is unwilling to follow that path. We expect to cooperate closely with our allies, including the EU, the source said. We donapost think we need an institutional treaty framework to achieve this.The UK is only looking to discuss legal agreements on much narrower elements of security cooperation, including to be able to share sensitive and classied information with the bloc. Britain will also not take part in the European Arrest Warrant and instead develop a new system based on Norway and Iceland. . Financial services

title: chinese takeaway served curry human
story: NewsChinese takeaway which served curry with human tooth keeps four-star hygiene ratingThe Newtown Road Cantonese Takeaway, in Worcester, will not be downgraded for cleanliness despite serving a pork curry with a human molar. The takeaways manager said he doesnt know where the tooth came from.ShareCommentsByTom HitchenorAnna MacSwan:,  FEB NewsThe tooth was found in a pork curry " to FREE email alerts from Mirror - daily newsSubscribeWe will use your email address only for sending you newsletters. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailA Chinese takeaway will be allowed to keep its four-star hygiene award despite serving up a meal containing a human tooth. Stephanie McDonough, , and partner David Burrows, , were shocked to find a large molar in a pork curry they ordered from the Newtown Road Cantonese Takeaway in Worcester last October. David, a warehouse operator, was a few mouthfuls into the dish when he discovered the object and spat it out. But following an inspection, health and safety bosses have said that while the find must have been unpleasant and stressful, there are no grounds for formal action. The restaurantaposs hygiene rating will therefore not need to be downgraded. The takeawayaposs manager, who only gave his name as Mr Chen, says there is no issue with cleanliness in his business. He added that all his staff are happy to be DNA tested to prove the tooth does not belong to them. The inspector checked all the staff to seewe have any teeth missing, which we donapost, he said. We donapost know where the tooth came from. If necessary, all of the staff are willing to do a DNA test to prove itaposs not our tooth. This inspection is proof that there is no problem at all with hygiene at the shop. Mr Chen added that the shop has had numerous prank calls since the incident, including customers asking for teeth in their meals. Hopefully customers will not jump to the conclusion about the tooth, he continued. We have a good reputation at the shop. It is a well-established business thataposs been going for over ten years. We would like to thank all our customers that still come to our shop. We are appreciative of their support. We can promise to maintain our standards and to get even better in the future.  Stephanie and David, who immediately lodged a complaint following their discovery, were offered a free meal and a full refund but only accepted the £. they had paid for the meal. Helen Cameron, food safety manager at Worcestershire Regulatory Services, says the body is satisfied that the restaurant takes all reasonable steps to ensure its food is safe to eat. A lab report has confirmed it was a human molar tooth that was passed to us by the complainant, she said.

title: coronavirus british chinese woman told
story: NewsCoronavirus: British-Chinese woman told to f***k off back to China in shock bus attackEXCLUSIVE: Lucy Sheen said the "stealth" attack aimed at her by a white man in east London is not an isolated incidentShareCommentsByRyan Merrield:,  FEB Updated:,  FEB NewsLucy Sheen was the victim of a stealth racist attack on a London bus she believes was in relation to coronavirus " to FREE email alerts from Mirror - daily newsSubscribeWe will use your email address only for sending you newsletters. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailA British-Chinese woman was left in shock after becoming the victim of a stealth racist attack on a bus in London which she believes was related to the coronavirus outbreak. Filmmaker Lucy Sheen was on her way to rehearsals when a white male passenger whispered in her ear: Why donapost you f**k off back to China and take your filth with you. The filmmaker was taken aback by the incident but said it is far from isolated. Only today I read of another incident on public transport where another East Asian female was taunted and called aposcoronavirusapos, she told the . Ms Sheen identies as transracial, having been born in Hong Kong in the s before being adopted in Britain - she then went on to study at the Rose Bruford College of Speech and Drama. She claimed racism of the kind she suffered on the bus is nothing new to British people of East Asian heritage or from overseas.Taking to Twitter on February  to vent about the incident, she used the hashtags #coronavirus and #racism.In my case, what shocked me was the stealth - the fact that this person had obviously made a decision to say what he did but do it in a covert manner.If he’d shouted that out I can deal with that, I could have handled that, she continued. It’s like any form of bias, prejudice or racism that is undercover, ingrained, institutionalised or structural, it’s very very hard to challenge or to try and change those entrenched views. Ms Sheen, who has dyslexia but has written, directed and acted in several celebrated productions - one of which appeared at the Venice Film Festival - feels todayaposs political climate has much to answer for.In the current climate along with the current government and what they seem to be supporting, it has given a great excuse for anti East Asian sentiments and [something for] racists to hang their racism upon. She said the bus incident made her feel both angry and deeply sad. I am British. I was born on the crown colony of Hong Kong, so British courtesy of the British Empire.  I was brought over to this country because of that. There have and will always be a minority who do not like [or] do not want people like me of whatever colour to be here. They see us as inferior and subservient and less than human because we are not white.But the temperature now post Brexit referendum and post new Conservative government and [Boris] Johnson as PM has become so racially toxic it feels like open season on [people of colour], and especially East Asians, [towards which]  racism has never quite been as unacceptable.
